results.title: Roslyn and Blagica: everybody needs a friend
results.creator_credit: James Ricketson, Richard Mordaunt, Jan Sharp and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our multicultural society”.
Discussion highlights a young Yugoslav girl’s desire to become Australian in order to gain acceptance and combat prejudice. By contrast, her Australian friend endorses the continuance of ethnic identity and customs and extols the virtues of a multicultural society.

results.title: Roads at work
results.creator_credit: John Milson, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Transport in Australia”.
The importance of roads in Australia as a chief means of communication and a basis of the entire transport system. Shows their early haphazard growth from bullock wagon tracks, and the highly specialised work involved in organising major roadworks, and traffic today.

results.title: Road to the West
results.creator_credit: Alex Ezard, Artransa Park Studios and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The story of the early days of Sydney Cove told by means of historical stills and by the re-enactment of the crossing of the Blue Mountains by Blaxland, Wentworth and Lawson, the resulting development and relics of that period, including the old Court House at Hartley. Today fast transport enables commuters to travel to and from Sydney and the Blue Mountains in less than two hours, passing through towns named after the three explorers.

results.title: Road observation
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “How to Drive”.
Shows what to look for in driving, the effect of speed on vision and typical signs and hazards.

results.title: Renewable energy in Australia
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Michael Rubetzki and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The film presents a range of alternatives to conventional energy sources for small-scale power requirements. Surveys the systems and technology currently available in Australia including wind, mini-hydro, biomass and photovoltaic systems.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philip Robertson, Michael Rubetzki and Film Australia

results.title: Reaching for the stars
results.creator_credit: Loch Townsend, John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian news and Information Bureau
results.brief_description: Shows Australian research in astronomy. Visits the observatory at Mount Stromolo, which houses big telescopes, cameras to map the skies, and the National Time Service. Goes on to show research on radio astronomy at the Radiophysics Laboratory (CSIRO), Sydney, and using Mills cross of stationary aerials and other devices. Pictures the windmill aerials at Dapto, used for tracking the sun

results.title: Ray of hope
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Maslyn Williams and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Designed for use in a national campaign against tuberculosis, this film describes the disease and preventive measures being taken to eradicate the disease from Australia. Shows the use of chest X-ray in detecting the disease; symptoms, nature and spread of tuberculosis; treatment of patients at sanatorium; importance of keeping children free from infection; use of BCG vaccine for the immunization of school children.

results.title: The Queen in Australia
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The Queen in Australia is a landmark in Australian history. It not only records the first visit by a reigning monarch to Australia, it was also the first colour, feature-length documentary made in this country. This historic program provides nationwide coverage of the 1954 Royal Tour by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and HRH the Duke of Edinburgh - a two-month journey that took in every facet of Australian life: garden parties at Government House, dancers at the Tivoli, racing at Randwick, tennis at Kooyong with Rosewall and Hoad, cricket with the Don, even a meeting with Papua New Guinean tribal chiefs. The young royals visited every state in the nation, and the result is a remarkable and revealing insight into our nation in the 1950s.

results.title: Project: Public Service
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Commonwealth Public Service as seen through the eyes of a school-boy preparing a project book on the work of the Service. The film also briefly outlines the functioning of the parliamentary system and role of the public servants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shan Benson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Populations
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Ecology Series”.
Describes most of the principles that cause animal and plant populations to look and behave as they do. Notes the constant change of populations, why this happens and how plants and animals take steps to ensure their survival. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
